title: Paying for Alternative Treatments
author: Tara Parker-Pope; Topics Nytimes Com; Top; Reference; Timestopics; People; P; Index Html
description: Patient Money columnist Walecia Konrad offers financial guidance for those who choose to take the medical path less traveled.
cleaned_text: The debate about alternative therapies rightly focuses on whether a particular herb or remedy actually works. But in today's Patient Money column, Walecia Konrad explores a much-neglected aspect of alternative care: how do you pay for it? She writes: So-called complementary and alternative medicine — or CAM, as it is known by practitioners and adherents — is becoming more mainstream every day. In 2007, more than one in three adults and nearly one in eight children, according to a federal study sponsored by the National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine, a division of the National Institutes of Health, used some form of CAM — from self-prescribed nutritional substitutes to repeat visits to alternative health care practitioners. So commonplace are the alternative providers that chiropractors and acupuncturists, for example, are now licensed by most states. At the same time, many traditional medical doctors, recognizing patients' demand for alternative therapies, have signed up for training in alternative therapies or added alternative professionals to their staffs.
